release dates: USA::27 June 2008                            (New York City, New York)

2.title: Free Lunch
2.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, questions about school funding emerge with the recent rollout of the Free School Lunch program for all of New York City's public schools. A Sikh organization funds a million-dollar educational ad campaign at a time of increasing hate crimes in the U.S. Then, we meet Pamela Yates, the director of 500 Years, a new film that tells the story of indigenous Mayans in Guatemala fighting an oppressive government.

4.title: On the Rocks
4.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we return to the Rockaway peninsula five years after Hurricane Sandy. Where is the beach recovery process? Do residents feel safe as the threat of more powerful storms become more prevalent? Who feels invisible in this entire process. We get answers to these and other questions.

7.title: Heat Seeker
7.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we meet one of the creators of Heat Seek, the latest device in the effort to make landlords more accountable to their tenants during the winter months. What are books deserts and what's being done to get more students to read. Then, part two of our look at how the Smithsonian is diversifying its staff and the art on display.

10.title: Transportation Frustration
10.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources hosted by Zyphus Lebrun, we ride along with a commuter (or dollar) van driver and we learn about the history of these vehicles that have been viable alternatives to the MTA in communities of color. We see how changing neighborhoods are affecting their future. Then we hear from Chinese immigrants who are fighting City Hall in their effort legalize their "e-bikes," or motorized delivery bikes.

1.title: What Is Ethnic?
1.plot: On this episode profiles New York's two oldest ethnic newspapers, the Jewish Forward and Amsterdam News and explores the meaning of the terms "ethnic" and "mainstream".

2.title: Journalists Under Fire
2.plot: This episode looks at the risks journalists around the world face every day. For some journalists from other countries who have now settled in the US, practicing their profession back home was a dangerous endeavor. They sometimes did so under the threat of imprisonment, torture and even death. In this episode we meet Roozbeh Mirebrahimi, an Iran journalist who was imprisoned and tortured for his reporting. We also profile Nowy Dziennik, the largest Polish newspaper published in New York City.

3.title: The Media and the Olympics
3.plot: On this episode editors from the two largest Chinese language papers join for in studio discussion while journalist and author Dave Zirin speaks talks sports. We also take a look at the mainstream media's coverage of the Olympics through the eyes of the Chinese community. Plus, coverage of the Beijing Olympics in Russian and French publications.

4.title: Ethnic Media and the Elections
4.plot: On this episode ethnic reporters talk about their experiences covering the Republican and Democratic conventions. We also hear from the Editor in Chief of the Pakistan Post who offers his views on the presidential race.

39.title: Surviving the Times
39.plot: This episode explores how ethnic media papers are surviving while some of their mainstream counterparts are floundering during the economic downturn. Lives of refugees from the Western Sahara. Role of Jewish matchmakers in the Orthodox community and HITN, one of the leading Spanish television stations in New York City.

31.title: Up Newtown Creek
31.plot: This episode looks at the 2nd largest oil spill in U.S. history. The bitter battle between proponents of a proposed soda tax and those who think it unfairly targets minority communities. Gay immigrants speak out on assimilating in the United States. And, why the orthodox Jewish community is upset about the appointment of a female Rabbi.

1.title: Nobody's Backyard
1.plot: This episode addresses Brazil's future as the Latin American giant looks forward to a runoff election at the end of October. Why Latin America is making a bold step towards no longer being the "yanqui's" backyard. Then, how one journalist is reinventing himself on the World Wide Web.

21.plot:

22.plot:

23.title: What's in a Name?
23.plot:

24.title: The Al Jazeera Effect

26.title: Fad or Revolution
26.plot:

 Be the first one to add a plot.

3.title: Lengthening Food Lines
3.plot: This episode explores how NYC pantries struggle with budget cuts and a wave of new clients brought on by the economic recession. Controversial business signs in Flushing's Chinatown. And, a Spanish theatre makes a home for itself on the Lower East Side.

18.title: Indians in America
18.plot: This episode focuses on New York City's skyrocketing Indian population. What's behind the trend and how is one mainstream newspaper trying to target the community? Then, we profile a tailor who has made his profession into a big business in more ways than one.

22.title: Making Waves
22.plot: This episode talks about how low power radio stations are trying to make their way back onto the airwaves in ethnic communities. Then, a debate surrounding the word "minority" as the United States' population becomes increasingly ethnic. And, a botánica owner in Spanish Harlem who is trying to change with the times.

23.title: Defending Food Deserts
23.plot: This episode looks at the trend towards more urban farming in New York and the connection to food deserts. Then, the scourge of rape during wartime.

24.title: Stop and Frisk
24.plot: This episode explores the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender community's response to the NYPD's stop and frisk policy. We learn about why the number of immigrant small business owners is at an all time high in the United States. Then, a few soccer aficionados are using their love of the sport to help high school students.

25.title: Reporters Uncensored
25.plot: This episode explores a project for international journalists covering under reported issues. Learn more about Hollywood's Polish pioneers. Then, meet a photojournalist who says it's more dangerous than ever to be in her profession.

1.title: Redrawing the Lines
1.plot: This episode covers the battle over redistricting. What's at stake when these district lines are redrawn in the city? Also, suicide amongst gay men of color with the editors of a new anthology on the issue. Then, how filmmakers in one Brooklyn community are using comedy to address the issue of gentrification in their neighborhood.

2.title: Summer of the Gun
2.plot: This episode examines why gun violence is up in New York City despite the police department's claims that the city is the safest it's been in years. Two filmmakers talk about their new documentary that highlights the history of Latin American immigration to the United States. Then, a program that's helping young women deal with real-life problems through drama.

40.title: 2013 Election Special
40.plot: This episode profiles an Indian-American candidate who is running in a majority Eastern European district, we take a look at ethnic groups trying to become the political powerhouses of tomorrow, and we see why some in the ethnic media think that one of the forerunners in the Mayoral race may have a hard time courting ethnic voters.

1.title: 9/11 Special
1.plot: This first episode of the sixth season, commemorates the 12th anniversary of the September 11, 2001 Terrorist Attacks with a special episode seeing how the attacks affected New York's ethnic communities. First, we investigate the influence of 9/11 on immigration reform. Then we see how Brooklyn's Pakistani community is still dealing with the consequences of massive deportations and law enforcement scrutiny. After that, we highlight how Chinatown has attempted to rebound from the attacks. Finally, we hear how one organization is trying to get recognition for many of ...

17.title: Dealing with the Detained
17.plot: This episode profiles immigration activists who want the New York City Department of Corrections to end their practice of detaining immigrants, who've committed minor legal infractions, for Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). Also, a tech company that is trying to help more low-income New Yorkers find jobs on line, and how a profile of how the beleaguered Affordable Care Act is already having a positive impact on one community health center in East Harlem.

3.title: Rezoning Chinatown
3.plot: On this week's edition of Independent Sources hosted by Garry Pierre Pierre, we talk about the brewing battle between the Department of City Planning and the Chinatown Working Group about the future of low income and affordable housing in the enclave. Then we speak to Zetta Elliot about her new children's book, "Dayshaun's Gift," that's one part magical adventure and another part social commentary.

8.title: Street Fight
8.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we learn about The Police Reform Organizing Project - PROP, a grassroots organization that's taking its campaign against the NYPD's "broken windows" policing to the streets. Then we speak to the director of a film called, 9-Man. The documentary explores elements of Asian American history and notions of masculinity through a sport whose popularity in Asian American culture can be compared to that of football in America.

10.title: Destination: Cuba
10.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we talk about whether Cubans should be cautious or optimistic about the impending changes that are sure to accompany the crush of US investment on the island. Then we hear about how the privatization of public spaces may be curtailing free political speech.

12.title: Homeless NYC
12.plot: This special episode takes a look at homelessness in New York City. One statistic from the Coalition for the Homeless estimates, that there are nearly sixty thousand people sleeping in municipal shelters each night. There are others who believe that's only the tip of the proverbial iceberg. So are the numbers increasing or aren't they? In studio to talk about this issue are the Director of Policy at New York City Care for the Homeless and the Co-Founder and broker at Skyton Group. Skyton Group is a boutique brokerage firm that works with the city to provide affordable...

14.title: Hollywood Shuffle
14.plot: This episode discusses mainstream media's quandary when depicting people of color in film and on television. Then, a Journalist and Brooklyn College Professor Paul Moses talks about his book, "An Unlikely Union," that explores the historical relationship between New York's Irish and Italians.

17.title: Scapegoat or Criminal
17.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we examine the growing tension between some members of the Chinese American and African American communities over the recent prosecution of former NYPD officer Peter Liang. Then we focus on grocery store owners' anger over new legislation that many of them describe as government over legislating their sector.

21.title: Candidate Trump
21.plot: This episode examines Donald Trump's rise to power during this election season and how the Tea Party's success may have paved the way for his extreme policies.

22.title: Summer Job Hunt
22.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we talk about a proposed plan to overhaul the city's summer jobs program to provide paid jobs for the more than 100,000 high schoolers looking for employment each summer. We learn about an Internet campaign that's fighting back against colorism in the Indian community. Then we meet a chaplain who his following in his mother's footsteps by taking to the streets to help others in need and teaching others to do the same.

25.title: Fighting for the Underground
25.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Abi Ishola, we learn about a Brooklyn woman's battle with encroaching developers to save a building that was once part of the Underground Railroad. We meet an artist who is preserving indigenous Mexican culture through his art. Then a playwright talks about how writing a one-man show helped him come out to his Hispanic family.

26.title: A Window of Opportunity
26.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Abi Ishola, we hear how the NYC Department of Consumers Affairs and the Mexican Consulate trying to allay new immigrants' fear of banks and other financial institutions here in the United States. We share a few laughs with Actor/Director Victor Cruz and his new film, "The Stockroom." Then we meet the spoken word poet whose piece about interracial dating in an increasingly gentrified Brooklyn neighborhood has gone viral.

28.title: Security Risks
28.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Abi Ishola, we learn about the city's growing security guard sector and why it remains largely unregulated. We hear about street vendors and their efforts to get more legal permits instead of turning to the burgeoning black market. Then our very own Garry Pierre-Pierre talks to Abi about his photo exhibit on Vodou that he hopes can change how people view the practice.

31.title: It's in the Bag
31.plot: In this edition of Independent Sources, we talk about the hotly debated five-cent bag fee that will be levied on consumers who use plastic or paper bags when shopping. Then we learn about a regiment of all-Puerto Rican veterans whose contributions during the two World Wars and the Korean War were finally recognized with one of the US' highest military honors.

33.title: Generation Stand-by
33.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Abi Ishola, we highlight a new short film that explores the generation of young Puerto Ricans who are under employed and out of work. We learn about a society of black stamp collectors that owes its existence in part to legendary Olympian Jesse Owens. Then we profile an artist who has turned her love of coffee into art.

8.title: Next Generation NYCHA
8.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we talk about the calls for the New York City Housing Authority, NYCHA to be more transparent with its plan to address its budget shortfall and provide more affordable housing in New York City. We learn about the effort to draw attention to the rezoning effort along Jerome Avenue in the Bronx that could leave several hundred people unemployed. Then we learn about En Foco, a non-profit organization that's helping artists of color reach new audiences.

9.title: President-Elect Trump: What's Next
9.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we talk about what's next for President-elect Donald J. Trump after his recent victory. Will he back pedal on some of his policies and is the uproar over the appointments of his chief of staff and senior counselor a precursor of things to come?

14.title: United by Flavors
14.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we highlight a new book that explores the United States' ethnically diverse history by delving into the origins of eight essential ingredients. We learn about a group of costumed performers who're instilling more cultural pride in young African Americans by teaching them about the history of African royalty like Cleopatra and King Tut. Then we visit a distillery in the South Bronx that's making legal Puerto Rican moonshine.

21.title: Small Business, Big City
21.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, we learn about how the city is bucking a national trend and encouraging more immigrant entrepreneurs and people of color to open small business. Then we meet a young computer programmer who has started an app that highlights the diverse authors and characters in literature.

24.title: Lost in Translation
24.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Garry Pierre-Pierre, why is the city's court system failing its non-English-speaking immigrants. One woman's journey from undocumented immigrants, to high-powered Wall Street analyst, to immigration advocate. Then, some workers in Queens take to the streets to fight for their rights after a Homeland Security audit of their workplace.

26.title: Unhealthy Advertising
26.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Zyphus Lebrun, new research shows that some food and beverage companies are directly targeting high risk populations in the Bronx with advertisements for unhealthy food. We talk about the spike in hate crimes across the country. Then we learn more about the effort to get Americans to read more books featuring diverse characters and written by more authors of color.

33.title: The Hijab and the Athlete
33.plot: This episode takes a special look at female Muslim athletes and their growing role in the battle against Islamophobia in the United States. Guests include Bilqis Abdul-Qaadir who was instrumental in the reversal of the International Basketball Federation - FIBA's, ban on Hijabs and Aya Elsekhely who is trying to help other Muslim women in their athletic careers.

-1.title: Crisis Not Averted
-1.plot: On this edition of Independent Sources, hosted by Abi Ishola, we hear about the thousands of homeowners in various neighborhoods of color that are still suffering because of the rampant predatory lending that took place during the mortgage crisis. We talk about the effort to get more people to sign up for organ donation at a time when demand is at an all time high. Then we profile a Chinese immigrant who left her high-powered job as a corporate attorney to become a restaurateur.

imdb.title: Independent Sources
plot: New York's fastest growing news sector - the ethnic press. Each show features an in-depth profile of a news organization or a reporter, along with a news roundup.::Anonymous
